header.title: Students slam ‘tiny’ pod rooms they say are ‘not fit for humans’
header.postText: University students housed in new pod-style accommodation have moved out after a month due to ‘appalling’ living conditions.', 'University of West England Students (UWE) described ‘tiny’ Purbeck Court Flats as shipping containers ‘not fit for humans.’', 'The 21 8×10-ft en-suite ‘studio pods’ were installed in the Bristol university’s car park last month, in response to an increased demand for student accommodation', 'First years living there claim they have been taunted by other students in nearby halls of residence for ‘not living in real accommodation’.', 'Joe Oakes-Monger told the BBC he had decided to move out because it was ‘quite isolating’ to live in ‘a very confined space’.', 'He said: ‘It’s a strange place to spend quite a large part of your time in. There’s not really anywhere else to go.', '‘At the time [I moved in] I was desperate for accommodation, but I was pretty appalled. I couldn’t quite believe the prospect of spending a year there.’', 'He added that it was ‘not an appropriate living standard for a human being’.', 'Other complaints from students have include there being limited communal space, thin walls and being overlooked by an existing hall of residence.', 'The pods are costing residents £150 per week, whilst campus accommodation ranges from £111 to £183 per week.', 'Another student, Jack Fifield, said: ‘They [the university] say it’s a pilot scheme but they shouldn’t be testing it on live students.', '‘They need to reduce the rent and retroactively refund them.’', 'The university has said it will be evaluating the value for money of the new units.', 'It has plans to build a range of 2,000 additional student rooms on the campus, which will be ready by 2022.', 'A university spokesperson told the BBC the pods had been ‘used successfully elsewhere, including student accommodation at other universities’.', 'They added: ‘We are working closely with the students living in this accommodation to respond to their feedback.', '‘This will be used to inform our future accommodation plans and to see whether the pilot may be extended beyond this academic year.’', 'The university’s vice chancellor, Steve West, has offered to meet with students living in the pods and said a new communal space will be added soon.

commentThread.commentText: That final photo reminds me of boarding kennels for some reason - and the inside of the rooms looks not much bigger than a boarding kennel single pet size run. How the university has the cheek to charge that much is ridiculous. I've seen better looking three-bedroom council houses for half that price.

replies.commentText: My first year uni halls were pretty much the same size and came supplied with steel frame camp bed, and a desk from the 80’s that was covered in carvings and graffiti. Only difference is that room was £78 a week. £600 a month is enough to rent a flat.
For what it's worth, I live in a first floor 1 bedroom flat in Long Eaton, Derbyshire. I pay £358.00 a month in rent. That's about average for this area.
